awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Community College Accelerated CyberCorps Pilot Program
awd_abstract_narration:
Sinclair Community College (SCC; OH), Brookdale Community College (BCC; NJ) and Moraine Valley Community College (MVCC; IL) propose to increase the placement of highly qualified cybersecurity professionals in government positions for the Community College Cyber Pilot Program (C3P). This proposed project is in alignment with the National Defense Authorization Act of 2018. Through cohort-based learning, SFS scholars at each of the four-partner colleges will collaborate on activities and events, including student skills competitions, certification preparation workshops, visits to local federal agencies, and participation in job fairs. Experiential learning will allow students to gain skills from real cybersecurity vulnerabilities and attacks experienced by businesses and organizations. SCC is designated as a National Center of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense 2-Year Education (CAE-2Y) and MVCC is an Advanced Technical Education (ATE) National Resource Center.

The program will be based on several successful adult learning practices: cohort learning, experiential learning, competency-based education, and one-on-one, holistic student support. The objectives are to: 1) research, develop, and document new strategic roles community colleges can play in increasing the number of cybersecurity professionals employed in government sectors; 2) build effective collaborations between educational institutions, business, industry, and government; 3) prepare 24 Scholars For Service (SFS) to help meet government need for highly qualified cybersecurity professionals; 4) disseminate best practice models designed for replication by other colleges across the country, including: new protocols for conducting prior learning assessments to assist veterans in applying their education and experience to cybersecurity disciplines; and best practices for recruiting, selecting, and supporting non-cybersecurity Bachelor degree students through cybersecurity education programs (cohort models and success coaching).

Co-funding for this project is provided from the Advanced Technological Education (ATE) and NSF Scholarships in STEM (S-STEM) programs, reflecting alignment of the project with major emphases of the ATE program on involvement of community colleges and the S-STEM program on financial and co-curricular support for high-achieving students with demonstrated financial need.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
To address the growing need for cybersecurity professionals within government agencies, the National Science Foundation?s Scholarship for Service (SFS), Advanced Technical Education, and Scholarships in STEM programs co-funded three grants for community colleges to deliver SFS Cyber Corp programs on their campuses. This program is unique, in that community colleges offered terminal associate?s degrees to Scholars in information technology fields to enter a federal, state, local, or tribal government position related to cybersecurity upon program completion. Additionally, community colleges were the fiduciary agents in implementing the 3CP grant, whereas previous SFS programs required four-year colleges and universities to manage the SFS Cyber Corp program and provide subawards to feeder community colleges.

This pilot program, SFS Community College Cyber Pilot (SFS C3P), features  detailed evaluation findings from the Collaborative + Lead (C+L C3P) model. The three colleges participating in this model are Sinclair Community College (acting as the Lead), Brookdale Community College, and Moraine Valley Community College.

The specific objectives of C+L C3P are: 1) research, develop, and document new strategic roles that community colleges can play in increasing the number of cybersecurity professionals employed in government sectors; 2) build effective collaborations between educational institutions, business, industry, and government; 3) prepare 24 (Moraine Valley commited to preparing 8) Scholars for Service to help meet government need for highly qualified cybersecurity professionals; and 4) disseminate best practice models designed for replication by other colleges across the country. Scholars in this program are to be veterans of the Armed Services and/or have at least a bachelor?s degree in a non- cybersecurity field.

The accomplishments achieved by the C+L C3P consortium are the following:

1. Created a SFS Cyber Corp Toolkit. This toolkit contains tips for Optimizing Grant Award Success (www.cssia.org/wp-content/uploads/SFS-Toolkit-small.pdf). This Toolkit was developed from the lessons learned and recommendations gleaned from existing SFS PIs, project managers, and external evaluators.  The toolkit is intended to share best practices with others. Community colleges using this toolkit would have the ability to provide greater opportunities to underserved populations, veterans, returning adults pursuing career changes, and women.  

2. C+L C3P consortium of Moraine Valley Community College (MVCC), Brookdale Community  College and Sinclair College worked together to create a collaborative environment which enabled their SFS Scholars to gain valuable cybersecurity instruction and industry credentials. The teams at each institution established programs and services to enable participants to transition to gainful Federal Agency employment. The C+L model provided students with leadership opportunities and the ability to interact with scholars from other institutions and backgrounds. The C+L C3P consortium leveraged their Federal Agency and Industry contacts to provide opportunities and training for their Scholars to succeed. Federal Agencies are beginning to understand the value of being able to draw from a more diverse pool of candidates as trained by Community Colleges.

3. All seven MVCC SFS C3P Scholars successfully completed the college's A.A.S. IT Security Specialist degree and began employment at an OPM approved Agency to satisfy their commitment to the NSF SFS program MVCC had an eighth scholar drop out early in the program due to severe medical reasons.

  • Fabian Lopez- IT Security Specialist at the Defense Information Systems Agency (DISA)
  • Joseph Tiscareno- IT Security Specialist APPSW Infosec-Defense Finance & Accounting Services
  • Demond Cottrill- IT Security Analyst, Northern Arizona University
  • Adam Maca- Information Security Specialist, Moraine Valley Community College
  • Nick Mastej-Research Associate-Systems & Analysis Center-FFRDC
  • Chris Murray- IT Security Student Worker, Minnesota IT Services
  • Tamar Paine- IT Specialist, Veterans Administration

4.The SFS Toolkit was distributed to the NSA CAE (Centers of Academic Excellence in cybersecurity) 5 Regional Hubs for dissemination. The C+L C3P team also presented their findings and best practices for recruiting, selecting, and supporting non-cybersecurity Bachelor degree students through cybersecurity education programs (cohort models and success coaching) at the following conferences and workshops: CAE Symposium and PI meeting, 3CS, WiCyS, HI-TEC, the SFS Annual Job Fair, and DEF CON.

The goal of this project was to pilot multiple community college programs to test their ability to prepare veterans, underserved populations, and adult career changers for cybersecurity jobs with Federal Agencies.  An important element of this program was changing the perception of Federal Agencies in hiring community college graduates. This program would have the potential to not only increase the national cybersecurity workforce pipeline but at the same time increase diversity, inclusion, and equity within the Federal cybersecurity workforce.

The success of our graduates will impact the Federal Agency employment pipelines, perception of employers, and opportunities for other community colleges to participate in SFS programs in the future. The C+L C3P team represent a potential mentoring resource for community colleges interested in persuing the SFS Cyber Corp program in the future.

 


Last Modified: 10/07/2022
Modified by: John L Sands
